citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
* A circular growth was observed on the left side cheek of one adult male rabbit. The growth was an estimated one inch to
two inches in diameter, a half inch in height and was extending outwards. The applicant stated that the condition was first
noticed two to three days ago. At the time of inspection the applicant had not contacted the attending veterinarian.
Abnormal growths on the body can be indicative of injury or a disease process which may affect the health of the animal
and can cause discomfort. The applicant must have this animal examined by a veterinarian to obtain an accurate
diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan. The outcome of this consultation must be documented and provided to the
inspector upon request. The applicant must ensure that all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
* There was no written environmental enhancement plan for birds made available at the time of inspection. The
environmental enhancement plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan at a minimum must address
social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices and any exemptions. This plan shall
promote the psychological well-being of birds. The physical environment in the primary enclosures must be enriched by
providing a means of expressing non injurious species-typical activities. Species differences should be considered when
determining the type or methods of environmental enhancement. Lack of environmental enhancement could lead to
abnormal behavior patterns affecting the bird’s mental and emotional health. Dealers must develop, document, and follow
a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. This
plan shall be made available to APHIS upon request.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class B license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 20, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
* A circular growth was observed on the left side cheek of one adult male rabbit. The growth was an estimated one inch to 
two inches in diameter, a half inch in height and was extending outwards. The applicant stated that the condition was first 
noticed two to three days ago. At the time of inspection the applicant had not contacted the attending veterinarian. 
Abnormal growths on the body can be indicative of injury or a disease process which may affect the health of the animal 
and can cause discomfort. The applicant must have this animal examined by a veterinarian to obtain an accurate 
diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan. The outcome of this consultation must be documented and provided to the 
inspector upon request. The applicant must ensure that all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
* There was no written environmental enhancement plan for birds made available at the time of inspection. The 
environmental enhancement plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan at a minimum must address 
social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices and any exemptions. This plan shall 
promote the psychological well-being of birds. The physical environment in the primary enclosures must be enriched by 
providing a means of expressing non injurious species-typical activities. Species differences should be considered when 
determining the type or methods of environmental enhancement. Lack of environmental enhancement could lead to 
abnormal behavior patterns affecting the bird’s mental and emotional health. Dealers must develop, document, and follow 
a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. This 
plan shall be made available to APHIS upon request. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class B license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 20, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

n
